newsitem.title: ZAIRE: War and illness weaken Mobutu's grip on Zaire.
newsitem.headline: War and illness weaken Mobutu's grip on Zaire.

text.p: President Mobutu Sese Seko, one of Africa's longest-serving strongmen, has held power in Zaire for three decades but rebel advances and his poor health raise questions about how much longer he can do so.

Proclaiming himself the one symbol of national unity, he has maintained his grip on power with a blend of political acumen, military ruthlessness and the distribution amongst acolytes and opponents of his immense wealth.

But Zaire watchers and many Zaireans believe that a combination of ill health and a five-month offensive by rebels fighting to overthrow him have loosened the already token control his government holds over much of the country.
"No-one, not even his doctor, knows when President Mobutu will die," one Western diplomat observed. "The question for now is does he still have that Machiavellian capacity to influence events?."
For some, he does. "The answer is yes," the diplomat said.

Others disagree. "The Titanic is sinking and its captain is in a neck lock. It is a matter of time before the ship sinks. The question is whether Mobutu goes with his boots on or off," one Western analyst commented.
Mobutu, 66, has been absent from Zaire for all but a few weeks of the last eight months, recuperating from cancer surgery and radiation therapy in Europe. He is currently in France.
After seizing power in 1965, he was able to rely on Cold War allies to support him militarily in punishing the numerous rebellions of Zaire's turbulent post independence history.

But since October, when the east of the country was invaded by a combination of Zairean rebels and ethnic Tutsi forces from neighbouring countries, one-time friends such as the United States have shown little enthusiasm for coming to the rescue.

A motley coalition of Serb mercenaries, Rwandan Hutu militiamen and the remnants of Zaire's divided and demoralised national army is all that has stood in the way of the rebel advance -- and mostly not for very long.
Ironically, it may be the secret of Mobutu's past success that is his undoing.

"Everything was done to ensure that the army is in the state it is in today. It is not a question of paying the soldiers. They simply have no morale or spirit to fight this battle," one despairing senior government official told Reuters.
One regional analyst says soldiers have had virtually no training since the West cut off military aide seven years ago.
Civilian and military authorities have failed to coordinate over the handling of the war, often with bitter recriminations.
"No functional institutions have been created to link the civilian and military leadership. The military was always tied up with President Mobutu," the regional analyst said.
Zaire watchers say nurturing division -- whether among politicians or the military -- has been Mobutu's trump card.
He maintained rival military units to limit chances of a coup. Everyone, even his political rivals, dance to his tune.
Under a year ago, pundits predicted Mobutu, facing a divided political opposition, had a good chance of legitimising his rule by winning Zaire's first multiparty presidential elections.
Under the transitional constitution, set up after domestic and foreign pressure forced Mobutu to move towards multi-party politics, those elections should take place by July.
The revolt has changed that.
The rebel advance has created a ground-swell of support for rebel leader Laurent Kabila -- both in rebel-held areas and poor districts of the teeming capital Kinshasa.
"His army is an army of liberation and he must free us of from the dictatorship of Mobutu," commented opposition militant Jose Wasunde, 34.
Others are more cautious. "We do not want to leave one dictatorship only to start with another," student activist Albertos Mupa commented.
The fall on Saturday of Zaire's third city of Kisangani, the nerve centre of army operations, and the flight of soldiers there sent a shudder through some members of the ruling class.
Diplomats say that the way Mobutu handles the next phase could be critical for Zaire.
The rebels, who now hold one fifth of Zaire, accord Mobutu a role -- even if it is only to negotiate his own departure.
"There is no alternative to negotiating with Mobutu," rebel information chief Raphael Ghenda said in the east.
Kabila hinted after the fall of Kisangani on Saturday that a face-to-face meeting with Mobutu might halt the rebel steamroller -- or as he put it "constitute some kind of pause".
With the Kinshasa rumour mill speculating furiously about prospects for a coup, time may be running out even for that.
